andysigler makes useless things

Nodela

Appropriating Hard-To-Use Machines

27 Jan 2015

Making Hardware is Hard

It’s amazing how big a difference an interface can make. I made one for the Roland-Modela, a discontinued micro-milling machine, and I now find it to be a far more useful tool for milling PCBs.

The current version can be found on GitHub. Sadly, the Modela has a very small serial buffer, and the only known way to communicate with it is with Roland’s proprietary drivers installed on Windows. This means nodela must be run on Windows.

Starting With the Modela

I like to make my own microcontrollers, like the Arduino. It’s components come cheap (the processor is $3, the rest are pennies), and luckily I work as a researcher at ITP, which has acquired a fleet of machines this past year for assembling PCBs.

A year ago, the process of making PCBs was a bit of a nightmare, especially for a student and beginner. One tutorial that got me started was this one, by Marc Boon from 7 years ago. It works. But executing a job is slow, unintuitive, and hard to teach students on top of everything else they need to learn that semester.
